verb.description: Attach or fasten (someone or something) with string or similar cord.
examples: they tied Max to a chair
her long hair was tied back in a bow

verb.description: Restrict or limit (someone) to a particular situation, occupation, or place.
examples: she didn't want to be like her mother, tied to a feckless man
self-respect is closely tied up with the esteem in which one is held by one's peers

verb.description: Achieve the same score or ranking as another competitor or team.
examples: he tied for second in the league
Toronto tied the score in the fourth inning

noun.description: A piece of string, cord, or the like used for fastening or tying something.
examples: he tightened the tie of his robe

noun.description: A rod or beam holding parts of a structure together.
A thing that unites or links people.
examples: it is important that we keep family ties strong

noun.description: A strip of material worn around the collar and tied in a knot at the front with the ends hanging down, typically forming part of a man's business or formal outfit; a necktie.
A result in a game or other competitive situation in which two or more competitors or teams have the same score or ranking; a draw.
examples: there was a tie for first place

phrases: The smart thing to do is to control your drinking and if you have to tie one on, do it on your dime, after the party.
He must have really tied one on last night, though he couldn't remember the details.
I really must have tied one on, he thought groggily.
I don't drink but I feel like I tied one on the previous night.
Not every night is a great night for tying one on and staying out till dawn.
her husband is able to tie in his shifts with hers at the hospital
she may have developed ideas that don't necessarily tie in with mine
He has an interesting piece on the affair at History News Network, and ties it in to broader issues having to do with politics and the academy.
Anyone who ties it in with football is deluding themselves.
In Orkney it is tying a strength in archaeology to that subject's importance to local tourism.
origin: Old English tīgan (verb), tēah (noun), of Germanic origin.
